nodes.text: Conditional convergence hypothesis: cross-country per capita GDP growth (1960-1985) depends positively on initial human capital and negatively on initial per capita GDP once human capital is held constant

Method: cross-sectional OLS regressions for 98 countries using average annual per capita GDP growth 1960-1985 as dependent variable with White heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors and alternative weightings
Operationalization: initial human capital proxied by 1960 school-enrollment rates (secondary SEC60 and primary PRIM60); additional proxies include student-teacher ratios and adult literacy

Result: with school-enrollment and other controls held constant, estimated coefficient on 1960 GDP per capita (GDP60) is negative and significant (about -0.0075 per $1,000), implying higher initial GDP lowers subsequent growth

Result: initial human capital has a strong positive effect on growth — regression 1 coefficients 0.0305 for SEC60 and 0.0250 for PRIM60; partial correlation between human-capital proxy and growth is about 0.73
Evidence: unconditional simple correlation between GR6085 and GDP60 is near zero (0.09); but partial correlation controlling for human-capital and other regressors is strongly negative (-0.74)
Claim: human capital affects growth partly by raising physical investment and lowering fertility

Result/Evidence: investment ratios positively related to initial human capital (private investment correlates 0.64 with human-capital proxy); regression shows SEC60 and PRIM60 significantly positive for private investment and GDP60 negative

Result/Evidence: fertility (net fertility FERTNET) is strongly negatively related to human-capital proxies; regression shows SEC60 and PRIM60 have significantly negative coefficients while GDP60 is insignificant for FERTNET

Claim: measurement error in GDP or business-cycle fluctuations are unlikely to account for main findings unless errors persist over long periods; robustness checks using GR7085 and sample restrictions produce similar coefficients

Result: government consumption ratio (gc/y) has a significantly negative association with growth and private investment (example coefficient on gc/y about -0.12 for growth); public investment shows little robust positive effect

Result/Claim: political instability measures (revolutions REV and assassinations ASSASS) are negatively associated with investment and growth, interpreted as adverse effects on property rights though reverse causation is possible

Evidence: purchasing-power-parity deviation for investment deflator (PPIGODEV) is negatively related to growth (coefficient about -0.014); magnitude of deviation reduces growth, sign of deviation not important

Result/Claim: continent dummies for sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America retain significant negative effects on growth even after controlling for human capital, investment, fertility, government consumption, and instability, indicating unexplained adverse factors

Conclusion: empirical regularities support conditional convergence—poor countries catch up only if their human capital is high relative to income; human capital raises growth via higher investment and lower fertility; government consumption, market distortions, and political instability hinder growth; residual regional effects remain unexplained
